segments.text: Hello and welcome to Veterans of the Valley.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I'm Tom Turbyville.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It was called the bloodiest battle of World War II.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Adolf Hitler was making one last push for victory in Europe.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It was the showdown known as the Battle of the Bulge.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: From December the 16th, 1944 to January 25th, 1945 in the Ardennes Valley on the German-Belgium border.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Three German armies versus three American armies, plus three divisions of British troops.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: When the Battle of the Bulge was done, 81,000 Americans, 100,000 Germans were either killed, captured, or wounded.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: 800 tanks were lost on each side.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The Germans lost 1,000 aircraft.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: One of those Americans wounded was Armor Infantry Tech Sergeant Speck Gammon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Long retired now as Sports Information Director at Texas A&M, Speck Gammon and his wife Arla live in College Station.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Speck, welcome.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: First off, thank you for your service.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: When we talked a few years ago about your service and the Battle of the Bulge, I know you talked about the weather.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: at that time you're talking about in in the winter months and you said it was about as cold as you had ever been i guess that's one thing you remember about this was just how cold it was right oh it was it was the coldest i've ever been and uh we had foxholes there and if you and had put we dug side things down for our feet and i was lucky that i kept my feet up on mine but
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: When I got back in the hospital after I was wounded, there were a lot of soldiers who had gone to sleep and their feet had fallen down to the water and they had trench foot and just, they were black.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: They were in great pain.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: A lot of people lost their feet actually.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: They had to be amputated, right, because of that?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Uh-huh.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Indeed.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The Battle of the Bulls history tells us that that area, the Ardennes Forest, the Ardennes Valley, was really not a place that the Americans thought that the Germans would make this last push.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So therefore, the Allied troops really didn't armor it very much.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: They really weren't there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It was a surprise to you that that's where the Germans picked to make their last push.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: A surprise to the Americans, right?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It did surprise the Americans, I think, yes.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Talk about
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: the Battle of the Bulge and talk about just what led up to that and where you were.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: What was your job in World War II?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You were armor infantry.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: What was your job there leading up to that?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Well, I was a platoon sergeant in charge of a platoon, but we were in half tracks.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: We weren't foot soldiers.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: We were armored.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And we were just
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: driving on the Germans at this point and we thought the war was going to be over for long and we were surprised that they really made a stand there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And I know that one of the American divisions
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: was sort of surrounded by the German divisions, and one of the humorous things that comes out of history is that the Germans asked the Americans to surrender, and there was a famous quote that came out of that, wasn't there?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Yeah, the commander said, nuts.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: That was his answer to it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: He was not surrendering.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Indeed, that was General Anthony McAuliffe who made one of the shorter but more famous quotes of the war.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: He said, nuts, he wasn't going to surrender.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You dug foxholes to sort of keep yourself warm because of the weather, because of the snow and the ice.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Made it very difficult to fight a war being that cold because you were just miserably cold just the entire time, right?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Well, I know that we had two wool outfits and you put on your wool pants
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And you found enough copies of Star of the Straps newspaper to wrap around that and then put your other second pair of pants over it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And actually that kept you fairly warm because the paper between the two pair of pants or shirts knocked off the wind.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right, right.

segments.text: He was killed with shrapnel from a mortar.

segments.text: People are shooting.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: What do you remember?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And I think everybody in combat was scared, or they didn't have good sense, but they weren't.

segments.text: They'd protect themselves, but we knew we had a job to do, and
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And we'd been trained well enough that whatever job you were in the platoon, you knew what you were supposed to do.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And that was something that you really weren't used to, especially because you were a journalist.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You were sort of trained to think on your own.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Well, we were moving in and...
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The winner that joined 1944 to 1945 was certainly one of the most historic of all wars.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Hitler's final defeat led to Germany's surrender, but it came at a mighty price on all sides.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The German offensive, called the Battle of the Bulge, was the worst conflict in terms of losses to American forces in the war.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We salute all the veterans today and a special thanks to Speck Gammon for his brave service in World War II.
